conclusion: To determine which container (D, E, or F) the liquid will flow into from outlets A, B, and C, we need to trace the paths the liquids take as they descend and encounter obstacles.
Liquid from A (orange) flows down and is obstructed by the purple and green bars.
Liquid from A merges with liquid from B and flows towards container E.
Liquid from B (blue) combines with liquid from A and is redirected by the green bar.
Liquid from B also flows towards container E.
Liquid from C (light blue) flows downward and is obstructed by the brown bar.
Liquid from C merges with the flow from A and B, eventually flowing into container F.
Containers D and E receive some of the mixture from A and B.
Container F receives liquid from C and some overflow from the mixtures.
The liquids from A, B, and C will primarily flow into containers E and F.
Final Answer: Liquid from A, B, and C will flow into containers E and F.
